conclusion: To determine the initial distance between the two cars, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph and use the information given about their motion during braking.
Car B has an initial velocity of 15 m/s and a final velocity of 5 m/s over a time of 20 seconds.

premise: Initial velocity \( u_B = 15 \, \text{m/s} \), Final velocity \( v_B = 5 \, \text{m/s} \), Time \( t_B = 20 \, \text{s} \)
conclusion: The deceleration of Car B is \( a_B = -0.5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).

premise: Deceleration \( a_B = -0.5 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), Initial velocity \( u_B = 15 \, \text{m/s} \), Time \( t_B = 20 \, \text{s} \)
conclusion: The distance traveled by Car B is 200 m.
Car A has an initial velocity of 25 m/s and a final velocity of 5 m/s over a time of 20 seconds.

premise: Initial velocity \( u_A = 25 \, \text{m/s} \), Final velocity \( v_A = 5 \, \text{m/s} \), Time \( t_A = 20 \, \text{s} \)
conclusion: The deceleration of Car A is \( a_A = -1 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).

premise: Deceleration \( a_A = -1 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), Initial velocity \( u_A = 25 \, \text{m/s} \), Time \( t_A = 20 \, \text{s} \)
conclusion: The distance traveled by Car A is 300 m.

conclusion: The initial distance between the cars is 100 m.

premise: If the two cars collide, the initial distance between them must be less than 100 meters.
